More Notes: Refers to increase in obese adults if annual mean temperature increased by 1 degree C. Equivalent to 12.3% increase.
Global warming significantly increased obesity rates in temperate zones.
Only caused a reduction in a small number of tropical countries.
Global warming-related increase in obesity rates projected.  Value is set to 0 due to lack of specific percentage information.  Increase is expected, but not quantified.
Global warming-related reduction in obesity rates projected in some tropical countries. Value is set to 0 due to lack of specific percentage information. Reduction is expected, but not quantified.
Population-weighted average marginal effect of a 1 degree C increase in temperature.
Projected increase in the number of obese adults due to global warming.
Attributed to increased obesity due to global warming.
The effect of warming on obesity is negative in tropical countries with a mean temperature above 27 °C. This value is a placeholder to indicate a negative effect.
This is the marginal effect mentioned in Column 1 without the interaction term. Data from 1975-2016.
1-unit increase in log GDP per capita reduces the effect of warming on obesity. Data from 1975-2016.
Higher impact in poorest versus richest countries. Data from 1975-2016.
Effect is higher for countries with oldest population compared to countries with youngest. Data from 1975-2016.
1-year increase in adult average age increases the impact on obesity. Data from 1975-2016.
1-year increase in average schooling of adults increases the impact on obesity. Data from 1975-2016.
Specifically, the estimates indicate that a 1 ◦ C increase in the annual mean temperature would increase the male obesity rate by 1.28 percentage points. The analysis uses data from 1975 to 2016.
Impact of global warming increases the female obesity rate by 0.81 percentage points; males are more exposed to the impact of global warming; result observed in data ending 2016
More days with temperatures under 9 °C would reduce obesity compared to the 12-15 °C bin. More days with temperatures above 15 °C would increase obesity.

The warming of high-temperature seasons (3 and 4) significantly increases obesity, while the warming of low-temperature seasons (1 and 2) has a negligible effect on obesity. Season definitions are based on temperature rankings across months within each country.
